title: Formation of low-temperature self-organized nanoscale nickel metal islands
abstract: The growth and evolution of nanometre-sized Ni metal islands deposited under low-temperature non-ultra high vacuum conditions as a function of metal layer thickness, growth temperature and time is reported. The temperature of formation of the islands has been intentionally kept low for possible applications in flat panel display technology and also to act as a catalyst for carbon nanotube growth. It is shown that the size and distribution of the islands depends critically on the annealing temperature and the initial thickness of the metal layer. The mechanism of formation of the islands is described in terms of an Ostwald ripening mechanism of mass transport of either weakly bound individual Ni atoms or smaller clusters into larger more dispersed clusters.

Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
 
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands 
 
J. D. Careya), L. L. Ong and S. R. P. Silva 
Advanced Technology Institute, School of Electronics and Physical Sciences, 
University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 7XH, United Kingdom. 
 
 
Abstract 
The growth and evolution of nanometer sized Ni metal islands deposited under low temperature 
non-UHV conditions as a function of metal layer thickness, growth temperature and time is 
reported.  The temperature of formation of the islands has been intentionally kept low for possible 
applications in flat panel display technology and also to act as a catalyst for carbon nanotube 
growth.  It is shown that the size and distribution of the islands depends critically on the anneal 
temperature and initial metal layer thickness. The mechanism of formation of the islands is 
described in terms of an Ostwald ripening mechanism of mass transport of either weakly bound 
individual Ni atoms or smaller clusters into larger more dispersed clusters.   
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
a) Electronic mail: David.Carey@surrey.ac.uk 
 1
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
1. Introduction  
The study of the self-assembly of nanometer sized metal and semiconductor islands has become 
particularly important in recent times as an attractive method for producing intrinsic nanoscale 
devices without the need for expensive lithography. Intrinsic limits imposed by the wavelength 
used in conventional deep UV lithography make this technique unsuitable for nanoscale device 
fabrication.  This leaves predominantly electron beam direct write-based fabrication techniques to 
define nanometer scale structures. E-beam techniques are expensive, time-consuming and 
generally have a lower throughput of devices.  It also requires the need for the substrates to be 
conducting which adds a further constraint to possible material systems that can be employed. By 
contrast, self-assembly on semiconductor surfaces is now well established allowing the production 
of regular arrays of structures such as quantum wells, wires and dots. [ 1 ] Oxide based 
nanostructures grown using self-organisation have also been reported from a range of metals such 
as Pd, Ir, Fe and Co. [2]  Nanometer sized barrier controlled devices which exhibit quantum 
conductance in metal-insulating-metal tunnel diodes have been fabricated through the use of 
current conditioning of metal oxides. [3]  In addition, there has been considerable interest in using 
metals on oxides for applications in heterogeneous catalysis where the size distribution, shape and 
wetting properties of the metal overlayer are important. Most of the research in this area has 
largely proceeded in terms of monolayer and sub-monolayer deposition under UHV conditions 
with particular emphasis on the electronic surface chemistry involved. [ 4 ]  Metal-on-oxide 
deposition is now emerging in the field of large area electronic applications that do not require  
UHV conditions where it is important to know what is the most likely topology of the surface that 
is produced as well as the ability to produce such surfaces over large areas and ideally at low 
temperatures. Temperature considerations are important since it is well known that heating 
deactivates many metal-on-oxide catalysts with surface reduction often occurring after annealing 
under UHV conditions above 725 K having been reported. [4]   
 2
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
One of the key aspects for technological applications is the need to be able to design the 
size and distribution of the nanoscale features that will be present. For example, it is advantageous 
to attempt to produce the same regular arrays of nanometer sized transition metal (TM) islands 
which can then act as catalyst template sites for the growth of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [5], which 
themselves have already been demonstrated as efficient electron sources in flat panel displays 
(FPD). [6] However, to date most CNT growth has proceeded by making use of metal catalysts 
annealed at high temperatures or in the form of powders making cleaning and adhesion to 
substrates problematic. Bower and co-workers [7] showed that thin films of sputtered cobalt could 
be used to produce metal islands to act as catalyst particles for CNT growth.  In that study, the Co 
substrates were heated to 825oC for CNT growth. High temperature (725oC) treatment was also 
applied to the magnetron sputtered Ni films by Chhowalla and co-workers. [8] In both these 
studies high temperatures were needed to facilitate the growth of the CNTs, however, a recent 
study has shown that carbon nanofibers, with a mean diameter of 45 nm, can be grown at room 
temperature over large areas using 4-7 µm (grain size) Ni catalysts particles. [9]  Growth was also 
reported up to 250oC and in this temperature range nm sized Ni acted as a catalyst in the ‘tip 
growth’ process. In this process the balance between C surface diffusion around the Ni particle and 
bulk diffusion through the particle is an important consideration. [10] Growth in both cases was by 
the lifting-off of nm sized Ni catalyst from the Ni particle in a rf plasma enhanced chemical vapour 
deposition (PECVD) system. Low temperature growth of carbon nanotubes has also been recently 
reported using a dc PECVD system. [11]  Nickel films of 6 nm thickness deposited using 
magnetron sputtering on a SiO2 substrate were patterned using a transmission electron microscope 
grid as a shadow mask and also by using electron beam lithography.  The former method produced 
large feature sizes (~10 µm) whereas 100 nm features were produced using the latter patterning 
technique. The two recent observations of growth at such low (macroscopic) temperatures points 
to the need for methodologies for the lower temperature formation of nm sized Ni islands and an 
 3
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
examination of their formation process without need for complicated lithography or the problems 
associated with residual catalyst particles. The size of the resultant catalyst sites of determines the 
growth properties of the CNTs themselves. An important consideration for a suitable catalyzed 
substrate is the ability to scale up the catalyst templates to macroscopic dimensions to a desired 
size for large area applications, such as field emission displays (FEDs). With a FED application in 
mind, optimizing the growth of Ni island substrates is important for temperatures below 500oC 
since it is above these temperatures that the glass used in conventional large area displays begins to 
soften. The growth of these islands is not confined to acting as catalyst sites for growth of CNTs 
alone with the natural protrusions themselves acting as a substrate on which a cathode material 
may be deposited. The cathode material, such as amorphous carbon thin films, will take the shape 
of the substrate and the size and shape of the islands can act as sources of geometric field 
enhancement allowing electron emission at low applied electric fields. [12]  In this paper the 
growth of nanoscale Ni islands as a function of temperature and film thickness is reported under 
non-UHV conditions. We show that it is possible by changing the metal layer thickness, 
temperature and growth time to alter the diameter and separation between the islands.  
 
2. Experimental details 
Substrates of n-Si were initially cleaned using a standard 3 stage ultrasonic solvent clean (acetone, 
methanol and isoproponal) and deionised water. A thin layer of Ti was evaporated on the 
substrates by heating Ti metal wire of known length in a suitable crucible in a vacuum of 5 x 10-6 
mbar. The films were then subsequently annealed in air to form TiO2 by annealing for 30 minutes. 
Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy was used to confirm the composition of the film. The 
oxide thickness is measured by having previously masked off part of the substrate and monitored 
using atomic force microscopy (AFM). The AFM images of the surface were taken using an 
ambient Digital Instrument Nanoscope IIIa operating in tapping mode.  Typical scan sizes were 4 
µm x 4 µm using a Digital Instrument J scanner.  Ni films (whose thickness was determined by 
 4
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
AFM) were then evaporated using high purity Ni wire of known length and subsequently annealed 
under flowing N2 at temperatures from 300oC up to 500oC for times of 10, 30 and 60 minutes.  It 
should be noted that the Ti and Ni evaporation times are not the same and the evaporation are 
performed for sufficient time to ensure that all the wire is used. The surface morphology of the 
films is monitored using the AFM.  Statistical analysis of the resulting metal islands was 
performed using the associated AFM software. Care was taken to ensure that only clusters were 
included in the AFM analysis using the methods available in the software.    
 
3. Results and discussion 
High resolution AFM measurements of the unannealed Ni films with a thickness of 8 nm (not 
presented here) show that the surface of the film to be extremely flat.  In general, there are three 
ways in which metal films can grow on an oxide layer, the mechanism of which depends critically 
on the affinity of the metal to react with oxygen [12]. Metals which possess high heats of 
formation of the oxide react strongly with the substrate and produce flat ‘wetting layers’.  Further 
deposition of the metal results in 2D layer-by-layer growth (Frank-van der Merwe growth) (Fig. 
1(a)) up until a critical thickness beyond which it is favourable for the accumulated elastic strain in 
the metal film to be relaxed to form dislocations. However, the strain energy can be lowered at a 
lower film thickness through the formation of discrete 3D islands via the so-called Stranski-
Krastanow (S-K) growth mode (Fig. 1(b)).  Weaker metal-substrate interactions are observed for 
the less reactive metals such as the noble metals.  In this case wetting of the substrate does not take 
place and agglomeration of the metal into 3D islands immediately takes place, Fig. 1(c). This is 
known as the Volmer-Weber growth mode. [13]  The first row transition metals bridge the gap 
between the strongly and weakly interacting metals with the metals to the left of iron being 
considered as ‘more reactive’ metals. The heats of formation of the oxide, –∆H, are for Ti 501 kJ 
per mol of O atoms (~5.2 eV) whereas that of Ni is 241 kJ per mol (~2.49 eV). [12] Since the 
value of –∆H for Ni is about half that of Ti the growth of Ni on a TiO2 will result in little 
 5
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
interaction with the substrate. This weak interaction of the Ni with the oxide has a number of 
important consequences. The low value of –∆H is important in determining if there will be a thin 
electron reduced surface layer.  It is know that the thickness of a reduced TiOx layer at the 
metal/TiO2 interface decreases as the magnitude of the heat of formation decreases. Diebold and 
colleagues noted that ~4 monolayers (ML) of reduced Ti are found at the Hf/TiO2 interface where  
–∆H per metal-oxygen bond is 5.8 eV. This decreased to ~1 ML in the Cr/TiO2 system (–∆H = 3.5 
eV) and 0.4 ML for Fe/TiO2 (-∆H = 2.8 eV). No reduced layer was observed in the Cu/TiO2 
system for which –∆H is 1.7 eV. [14]  Since the value of –∆H for Ni is 2.49 eV, intermediate 
between Cu and Fe it is not expected that a significant reduced TiOx layer will be formed.  In this 
way the study of Ni based layers is therefore interesting in its own right since it is at the interface 
between the strongly and weakly reacting metals. Furthermore the properties of as-deposited metal 
over layers are typically far from equilibrium and cannot be completely understood solely from 
thermodynamic factors. For example, the surface free energy oxides is lower than that of metals 
which would mean that all layers should form islands. Kinetic factors which effect mass transport 
and surface diffusion of material are therefore an important consideration.  
In Fig. 2 the evolution of the surface morphology of a series of Ni films with an initial 
metal thickness of 8 nm annealed for 30 mins as function of annealing temperature from 300oC to 
500oC (table 1, samples 1-3) is shown.  The morphology of the Ni film annealed at 300oC shows 
(Fig 2.(a)) evidence for the formation of small closely islands and an average diameter of 80 nm.  
Annealing at 400oC the film morphology changes with the formation of larger islands, with a mean 
diameter of 114 nm coupled with a larger inter-island spacing.  Finally, after annealing at 500oC 
large diameter islands (average diameter of 306 nm and a standard deviation of 97 nm)  can be 
seen in Fig. 2(c),  The resultant islands are also more isolated from each other.  The results shown 
in Fig. 2 demonstrate that annealing at successively higher temperatures results in the formation of 
isolated large diameter islands at the expense of smaller close packed islands.  Taking the room 
 6

temperature lattice constant of Ni to be 0.352 nm and that of the tetragonal TiO2 surface to be 
0.649 nm in the a direction and 0.296 nm in the c [001] direction [14] shows that the room 
temperature strains are εa  = –45% and εc = +19%, respectively.   This means that the deposition of 
Ni on TiO2 results in a high degree of compressive strain in the c direction and tensile stain in the a 
direction.  This stain energy is not substantially reduced since the coefficients of linear expansion 
[15] for Ni (13.4 x 10-6 K-1) and TiO2 (7.14 x 10-6 K-1 in the a direction and 9.19 x 10-6 K-1 in the c 
direction) are similar. The effect of annealing at high temperatures is to allow mass transport of 
either individual Ni atoms or small clusters across the surface in which larger clusters could be 
formed out of smaller clusters in a process analogous to Ostwald ripening. Evidence for Ostwald 
ripening effects was also observed for Cu overlayers on TiO2 where it was also noted the 
activation energy for diffusion of atoms will be of the order of 5-20% of the binding energy of an 
atom to its surface. Since both Ni and Cu have low interactions with the TiO2 surface, as explained 
previously,  low barriers for diffusion would be predicted. [16] In the study of Cu on TiO2 in 
reference 15, using X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, a value for the activation energy for the 
diffusion of only 0.13 eV was measured.  The increase in the standard deviation of the cluster 
diameter, table 1, as a function of annealing temperature is also consistent with a surface diffusing 
mechanism, since the size of an island will depend on the ability of Ni to be locally gathered from 
one site to a growing cluster.  Further confirmation of a surface diffusion hypothesis leading to 
larger islands can be found from the examination of the island density presented in table 1.  On 
thermal annealing the density of islands decreases from 32.6 µm-2 at 300oC (sample 1) by over an 
order of magnitude after annealing at 500oC (sample 3).  
 It is known that the initial thickness of the metal film can play an important role in 
determining surface morphology at a given temperature. [2,7]  We have examined the influence of 
using a thinner (less than 8 nm) initial Ni thickness to investigate this effect. Figure 3 shows the 
surface morphology of two films (samples 4 and 5) annealed at 400oC for 30 mins having an initial 
 7
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
Ni thickness of (a) 3 nm and (b) 5 nm, respectively. From Fig. 3(a) it is apparent that there is some 
evidence of island growth for an initial Ni thickness of 3 nm with a mean diameter of 67 nm.  At 5 
nm metal thickness larger islands (mean diameter 89 nm) are formed but this process is 
accompanied by an increase in the standard deviation of the island diameters.  
 Finally, we have also investigated the effects of different annealing times.  The samples 
previously discussed were all annealed for 30 minutes at their respective temperatures and Ni layer 
thickness. For films with a Ni thickness of 5 nm we found that even after 10 minutes (sample 6), 
evidence of island formation present (Fig. 4 (a)).  Island coverage was improved after a 30 minute 
anneal as reported previously reported in Fig. 3(b) for sample 5. In the case of a 60 minute anneal 
(sample 7) much more uniform island coverage can be seen consistent with the mass transport 
Ostwald ripening mechanism discussed previously.    
From these results we conclude that the two most important aspects in producing Ni islands 
are the annealing temperature and initial Ni layer thickness.  Annealing at higher temperatures 
produces larger diameter islands though further apart from one another. The weak interaction 
between the Ni and the oxide layer results in a low activation energy barrier to Ni migration which 
results in larger islands forming from smaller islands or weakly bound individual Ni atoms.  As the 
Ni cluster get larger they become more dispersed which may be an important in the growth of 
vertically aligned CNTs in which the presence of nearby tips can increase onset fields due to 
partial field screening. [17] A similar effect would also occur if the islands are templates for large 
area field emission arrays.  
 
4. Conclusion 
In conclusion, we have shown that it is possible to produce nanometer sized Ni islands by choosing 
the correct initial Ni thickness, annealing temperature and annealing time. It is found that the two 
most crucial factors are the annealing temperature and initial Ni thickness. For closely spaced 
island formation an optimum annealing temperature of 400oC was observed once the Ni thickness 
 8
Formation of Low Temperature Self-Organized Nanoscale Nickel Metal Islands    
was 5 nm or above.  For annealing at 500oC coalescence of surface atoms though diffusion results 
in larger well spaced islands.  The mechanism for island growth and possible applications to large 
area field emission arrays and catalysts sites for low temperature CNT have been discussed.
